title: Towards an agency-based philosophy of (advanced) technology
description: Most of temporary scientific research depends essentially on the employment of complex software, although scientists are usually not trained in programming and software engineering. From the perspective of Philosophy of Science (PoS) the increase in scientific software as research tools is of epistemic and analytic interest; and for Software Engineering (SE) the analysis and improvement of the architecture and algorithmic structure of software projects is important. Thus, both disciplines focus on the analysis of code and share the conjoint interest in the development of new domain-specific methods for the analysis of scientific (open) software projects.
collaborators: Prof. Dr. Anna Laktionova, Kate Hamburger Kolleg "Cultures of Research", RWTH Aachen University (in collaboration with Prof. Dr. Carl Mitcham, Colorado School of Mines)

title: Retrospective code-analysis for Open Science (WiRCA): Separating technical code from scientific code automatically for scientific programming in ordert to ease the evaluation of Open Science research software.

title: Society after Money. A Simulation.
description: Can we simulate post-monetary, or even non-monetary economies? Research on the commons has particularly inspired our approach to a society after money. Elinor Ostrom’s Nobel Prize for Economics in 2009 made clear that commons economies are possible, albeit locally restricted. Using agent-based modelling, we are experimenting with scaling up such local commons economies. This international research group of media scientists, economists and philosophers explores the collision of digital technology with the entity money.
collaborators: Prof. Dr. Jens Schröter (PI), Dr. Hanno Pahl, University of Bonn; Prof. Dr. Manuel Scholz Wäckerle, WU Vienna University of Economics and Business; Dr. Stefan Meretz, Commons-Institute Bonn; Prof. Dr. Gabriele Gramelsberger, Tobias Dumschat, RWTH Aachen University

title: Aux limites de l’expérience: Vers une phénoménologie de la science informatisée
description: The concept of experience is mostly taken for granted in philosophy of science and rarely undergoes a deeper study. The project argues that especially with the increasing use of computer simulations and machine learning, the concept of experience becomes crucial to understand the new interactions of scientists and their technological environments. To analyze this, an extension and rereading of Husserls concept of scientific experience will be developed.
collaborators: Prof. Dr. Natalie Depraz, Université de Rouen, Normandie and Husserl-Archive ENS Paris, Dr. Dawid Kasprowicz, RWTH Aachen University.

title: Biological Transformation of Technical Systems utilizing Antifragility Management
description: Antifragility can be observed in Nature as the increase in capability to thrive as a result of stressors, e.g., shocks, noise, faults. Antifragility differs from the concepts of resiliency (ability to recover from failure) and robustness (ability to resist failure). In this project we explore the possibility of transferring antifragile mechanisms from biology to engineering.
collaborators: Dr. Daniel Trauth, Marco Becker M.Sc., RWTH Laboratory for Machine Tools and Production Engineering (WZL); Prof. Dr. Ulrich Schwaneberg, Dr. Mehdi Davari and Dr. Tetiana Kurkina, RWTH Institute for Biotechnology; Dr. Dawid Kasprowicz and Prof. Dr. Gabriele Gramelsberger, RWTH Theory of Science and Technology
fundedBy: DFG Initiative of Excellence / ERS RWTH

title: Digital Literacy
description: If science and engineering become increasingly computational, how can computational knowledge and skills be communicated to B.A. and M.A. students? Based on interviews we explore the digital literacy of researchers, lecturers and students in mechanical engineering. Together with the RWTH Faculty of Mechanical Engineering our goal is to develop a digital literacy indicator for teaching in engineering.
collaborators: Prof. Dr. Gabriele Gramelsberger, RWTH Theory of Science and Technology; Prof. Dr. Sven Komma and Dr. Ilona Cwielong, RWTH Institute of Educational Science; PD Dr. Malte Persike, RWTH CLS Center für Lehr- und Lernservices

title: Neuro Modelling Talk(completed)
description: The goal is to develop a conceptual framework for understanding generalization in neuroscientific modelling, because generalization is a major challenge for contemporary Computational Neuroscience and Neuromorphic Computing. Without generalization comparability of models can't be achieved, in turn, reproducibility of results isn't possible, and it is difficult to give guidance to the design of neuromorphic systems. Furthermore, without generalization of models scaling-up complexity isn't possible (complexity barrier), thus, hindering progress in knowledge. Therefore, we want to conceptionally explore generalization and evaluate new ideas on generalization about their practical feasibility.
fundedBy: DGF Initiative of Excellence / ERS RWTH Aachen University
collaborators: Prof. Dr. Gabriele Gramelsberger and Lisa Schüttler, RWTH Aachen University; Prof. Dr. Markus Diesmann, Dr. Johanna Senk, Dr. Tom Tetzlaff and Dr. Sache van Albada, Institute of Neuroscience and Medicine (INM-6) at the Research Centre Jülich

title: Mind the Game!(completed)
description: Artificial Intelligence (AI) dominates the discourse on future society. While most of the smart cars, robots, and algorithms discussed by the broader public have yet to be developed in academic and industrial labs, the massive exposure of users to AI in computer games is part of everyday experience for millions. Thus, our main hypothesis is that AI is not a future technology, but has long since invaded the living rooms of our society today, opening up an unexplored 'sociointelligent space'. Mind the Game! explores this socio-intelligent space of AI in games that interact with users theoretically, empirically, and technologically.
collaborators: Prof. Dr. Markus Rautzenberg (PI), Folkwang University of the Arts; Prof. Dr. Gabriele Gramelsberger (Co-PI), RWTH Aachen University; Dr. Serjoscha Wiemer, University of Paderborn; Dr. Matthias Fuchs, Leuphana University Lüneburg; Kay Bennemann, Ubisoft Blue Byte Düsseldorf

title: NRW Digital Fellowship 2017 (completed)
description: The CSS Lab as a lab for teaching Computational Science Studies has been partly funded by the NRW Digital Fellowship; in particular, the development of ICE Isomorphic Comment Extractor and ICA Isomorphic Class Analyzer, the CSS Lab website as well as the development and communication of the GovTec Master's modules Knowledge Theory of Research, Modelling for Innovation and Practice. The CSS Lab provides a digital environment for computational science studies for Master students as well as PhD students.
fundedBy: Stifterverband and the NRW Ministry of Research
collaborators: Prof. Dr. Gabriele Gramelsberger and Dr. Dawid Kasprowicz, RWTH Aachen University

title: Computer Signals. Art and Biology in the Age of Digital Experimentation II(completed)
description: In this project, an international research group of biologists, artists, philosophers and historians of science explores aspects of producing and processing data in the biosciences. Computer Signals II is based on the examples of two working groups in the biosciences, one on Helgoland, the other in Austin, Texas. The project concretizes their various research questions from the perspective of art, thereby lending crucial impetus to the overall project: How can the materiality of digital data processing be captured and represented? How can the formative involvement of digital devices and their infrastructures in the acquisition of knowledge be shifted into human perception, and how can their contribution be made tangible, i.e., accessible to human experience?
collaborators: Prof. Hannes Rickli (PI), Dr. Birk Weiberg, Valentina Vucic, all ZHdK Zürich University of Arts; Prof. Dr. Hans Hofmann, Texas University Austin; Prof. Dr. Philipp Fischer, Alfred-Wegener-Institute Helgoland; Prof. Dr. Christoph Hoffmann, University of Lucerne; Prof. Dr. Hans-Jörg Rheinberger, Max-Planck-Institute of History of Science; Prof. Dr. Gabriele Gramelsberger, RWTH Aachen University

title: Atmosphere & Algorithms (completed)
description: This scientific network of meteorologists, philosophers and historians of meteorology explored the epistemic shifts in atmospheric modelling and simulation. Five meetings were held between 2012 and 2014 at the Rachel Carson Center in Munich; the Munich Re Corporate Climate Centre; the DLR/IPA Institut für Physik der Atmosphäre, in Oberpfaffenhofen/Munich; the University of East Anglia, Norwich; and the Centre Alexandre Koyré in Paris. The network resulted from a preliminary exploratory workshop on 'Exploring Epistemic Shifts in Computer-Based Environmental Sciences' at the University of Aarhus in 2010, funded by the ESF European Science Foundation. This was followed by a conjoint panel on 'Cultures of Prediction' at the 6th European Society for the History of Science (ESHS) conference in Lisbon in September 2014. Although its funding has lapsed, the network remains active.
principalInvestigators: Dr. Gabriele Gramelsberger, FU Freie Universität Berlin; Prof. Dr. Matthias Heymann, Assoc. Professor, University of Aarhus together with 16 researchers from 8 European countries
publicationInfo: The main publication of the network was released in 2017: Heymann, Matthias, Gramelsberger, Gabriele and Mahony, Martin. (eds.) (2017). Cultures of Prediction in Atmospheric and Climate Science: Epistemic and Cultural Shifts in Computer-based Modelling and Simulation, (Routledge Environmental Humanities). London: Routledge/Francis & Taylor.

title: Embodied Information - Lifelike Algorithms & Cellular Machines (completed)
description: The convergence of technologies like information and bio-sciences, and also nano- and neurosciences, characterises the recent challenge in science and technology, promising new technological outcomes like nano-bio processors, smart dust and innovative materials. Because manipulating matter on the nano scale, information bit by bit, and life on the scale of cells and neurons raises the hope of creating a new form of science and technology, convergence is being hailed as the new paradigm of the 21st century, suggesting the 'unity of nature'.
collaborators: Dr. Gabriele Gramelsberger (PI), Dr. Werner Kogge, Nina Samuel, all FU Freie Universität Berlin together with Prof. Peter Bexte, Kathrin Friedrich, Michael Putzmann, all KHM Academy of Media Arts Cologne. In cooperation with Prof. Dr. Adrian Mackenzie, ESRC Lancaster University
publicationInfo: The main publications were released in 2013 and 2014: Gramelsberger, Gabriele, Knuuttila, Tarja and Gelfert, Axel. (eds.) (2013). Special Issue: Philosophical Perspectives on Synthetic Biology. In: Studies in History and Philosophy of Biological and Biomedical Sciences, 44(2); Gramelsberger, Gabriele, Bexte, Peter and Kogge, Werner. (eds.) (2014). Synthesis. Zur Konjunktur eines philosophischen Begriffs in Wissenschaft und Technik. Bielefeld: Transcript.
fundedBy: BMBF German Federal Ministry of Research

title: Computer Based Simulations-New Tools of Knowledge Production (completed)
description: Science has been using computer simulations since the 1950s. Expanding computer capacity, the development of simulation tools and algorithms, and increasingly complex visualisation technologies have established computer simulations as powerful instruments of scientific knowledge production beside theory and experimentation. Simulations can be regarded as activities in a virtual laboratory setting – comparable to experimenting in a laboratory setting. This method of knowledge production is determined by various conditions: the digital and algorithmic processing of data, modelling, and using computer power to run the models. These conditions restrict simulation-based knowledge production and yield a methodologically inherent potential of uncertainty. Efforts to keep the uncertainties within an acceptable limit of error tolerance are forcing the focal question about the methods and practises used to construct simulation models and to validate their results.
principalInvestigators: Dr. Gabriele Gramelsberger, FU Freie Universität Berlin
publicationInfo: The main publications were released in 2010 and 2011: Gramelsberger, Gabriele. (2010). Computerexperimente. Zum Wandel der Wissenschaft im Zeitalter des Computers. Bielefeld: Transcript; Gramelsberger, Gabriele. (ed.) (2011/2015). From Science to Computational Sciences. Studies in the History of Computing and its Influence on Today‘s Sciences. Zürich, Berlin: diaphanes/Chicago: The University of Chicago Press; Gramelsberger, Gabriele and Feichter, Johann. (eds.) (2011). Climate Change and Policy. The Calculability of Climate Change and the Challenge of Uncertainty. Heidelberg, Berlin: Springer.
